idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.0.0.535

descript.abstract: This polygon of the island without small bay islands was created by making a continuous line from the bay2003 shoreline by closing up creek openings. By merging the shoreline0403 with the bay_withoutislands layer, and then using XToolsPro to create a polygon from this continuous polyline.
descript.purpose: For many complex spatial analyses a polygon is necessary for clipping data to the extent of the island. This cannot be accomplished with only the bay shoreline polyline and thus, a polygon is neccessary.

citeinfo.origin: Biological Science Technician, GIS department, Summer 2004
citeinfo.title: Assateague Island National Seashore Island Polygon (2003)

citeinfo.origin: Biological Science Technician, GIS department, Summer 2004
citeinfo.title: ASIS Bay Shoreline October 2003
citeinfo.othercit: This was the polyline file used to create the bay side of the polygon. The tiny islands off the main island shoreline were deleted and the creek dangles were closed and corrected. This data was created by digitizing the shoreline from aerial photographs taken in October 2003.

citeinfo.title: Shoreline0403
citeinfo.othercit: This was the polyline shapefile used for the beach shoreline. It was created in April of 2003, the closest available complete shoreline date to the October 2003 aerial photographs (used to digitize the bay shoreline). This data was created by riding an ATV with a GPS down the shoreline and taking readings along the way.

citeinfo.title: Metadata for Assateague Island National Seashore Island Polygon (2003)

distinfo.distliab:
The National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics (i.e. "GIF or JPG" format files) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such.
The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they are derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are inteded to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data.
The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on computer systems at the National Park Service, no warranty expressed or implied is made reagrding the utility of the data on other systems for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.

procstep.procdesc: This shapefile was created by merging the bay shoreline digitized from aerial photographs of October 2003 (bay2003) and the beach shoreline mapped with a GPS in April of 2003. Each of these shapefiles was modified slightly to ensure that there were no overlapping polylines and dangles. Then the files were merged using the Geoprocessing Wizard in ArcMap. Finally, using the XToolsPro extension, one polygon was created from many polylines. NOTE: for analysis purposes please note that the bay shoreline represents relative low tide while the ocean shoreline represents relative high tide.

The bay shoreline, used to create this polygon, was digitized on-screen from October 2003 aerial photographs using an extensive list of methodology and situational solutions. The water-land boundary was digitized at a 1:500 scale from the photographs which were taken at near-low tide conditions. Entrances to creeks and canals were not delineated in their entiretly, but only if wider than 3m, and interior ponds were also not delineated. The remaining procedures can be found in the Word document with the following linkage: G:\Electronic_Library\10_Geomorphology\05_Shoreline_Processes\Documentation\bay2003_methods.doc

The ocean shoreline from April 2003, used to create this polygon, was accomplished by driving a 4 wheel ATV at a relatively constant speed along the identified high tide line. For the purposes of this monitoring program, the actual ocean "shoreline" was defined as the average position of the most recent high tide, evidenced by the obvious wet/dry sand line or deposited wrack. The GPS receiver was configured to record positions at a very short interval (1 position every 2 seconds) for the best representation of the shoreline position.

dataqual.logic: This data contains the entire coastline for Assateague Island. The bayside being digitized from 2003 aerial photography and the ocean side was collected by GPS.
dataqual.complete: This data contains the entire coastline for Assateague Island.
